Award.AwardTitle: ASME 2014 3rd Global Congress on Nanoengienering for Medicine and Biology, Feb 2-5, 2014 in San Francisco

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: Nanotechnology has tremendous promise in improving the human health through better imaging, diagnostics or drug delivery. AME2014 International Congress on NanoEngineering for Medicine and Biology (NEMB 2013) will help catalyze and spur on this field by bringing together leading academics with interests in experimental and theoretical aspects of nanotechnology. These experts will discuss topics related to improved prediction of nanoparticle delivery in the body, to novel strategies for using nanomaterials for disease detection and for construction of diagnostic platforms. The exchange of ideas and interactions afforded by this conference will help identify problems and possibilities and will lead to new collaborations and new concepts in the field of nanotechnology and nanomedicine.

Institution.Name: University of Minnesota-Twin Cities
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

Performance_Institution.Name: ASME Global Congress on Nanoenginering for Medicine and Biology

POR.DRECONTENT:
NEMB 2014 Outcomes:

Our goal for NEMB 2014 was to bring together reading experts inbiology, medicine, nanomaterials, and engineering so as to review experimental methods, synthetic methods, results, models, computations, analyses and innovative methodologies for sensing, quantifying, diagnosing and treating medical disorders using engineering approaches. These are emerging areas that are of greatest importance not only for Nano-Biosensing and Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems (CBET) but also for engineering and science in general, and for the development of new technologies in particular.

 

NEMB achieved the following:

–Five tutorials –7 plenary talks –45 technical sessions

–International attendees from many countries:

     Australia, Brazil, Britain, Denmark, Germany, Italy, Japan, Singapore

 –Poster session featuring 88 presenters

–Awards ceremony for poster presentations

 –Federal and industry funding from the following entities included:

  NSF, NIH •Agilent, Bose, Royal Society of Chemistry, NanoReviews,

Virginia Tech, among others

 

The Conference Model is Unique:

Organizers built the conference as follows: 1.) defined nine themes (tracks) 2.) secured high-level plenary speakers 3.) selected track chairs: at least one senior and one junior faculty per track 4.) empowered track chairs to select session chairs, invite keynotes, and build sessions 5.) constructed sessions with a mix of senior, high-level keynotes and presenters, as well as students and junior faculty

 

The publication structure was presentation only abstracts for talks and posters.

Over 300 attendees with overall high satisfaction and feedback.

 

We achieved a Year of “Firsts”

•First-ever live webcast from an ASME conference. Conference registrants can access the archived talks at no extra charge following the conference

 •“Audience Choice” Poster Award: Attendees can vote via mobile devices using the ASME \ Itinerary Planner during the poster session

http://www.asmeconferences.org/NEMB2014/ItineraryIntro.cfm

•Promotional podcast recorded: https://www.asme.org/engineeringtopics/

media/nanotechnology/nanoengineering-medicine-biology-congress-2014

•Recording of video interviews with attendees onsite

•Live tweeting #NEMB2014

 

Where was the funding used?

The funding went to both students and faculty. Specifically, 31% of the funding was used to support students (including graduate and post doctoral) and the remaining 69% for faculty. More than 25 students and 40 faculty were supported.  Of the students supported 7 were post docs and 18 were PhD students. Of the faculty supported, there were 4 junior faculty, 21 keynote, 5 tutorial, 11 featured and international speakers. The ability to help these students and faculty attend the meeting with reduced registration and travel had a huge impact on the quality of the meeting.

 

 


Last Modified: 08/30/2016
Modified by: John C Bischof
